ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by MRI showing a 13mm tumor in the left internal auditory canal; consistent with absent acoustic reflexes and high-frequency asymmetry.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cochlear Hydrops
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initially considered due to aural fullness and slight low-frequency asymmetry, but ruled out by subsequent testing and imaging.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Lateral Semicircular Canal Dehiscence
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to possible conductive component in low frequencies, but ruled out by normal bone conduction and imaging.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and check for asymmetry.
To evaluate speech recognition abilities in quiet.
To assess middle ear function and rule out conductive pathology.
To assess retrocochlear pathway integrity; critical for detecting retrocochlear pathology.
To visualize retrocochlear structures and confirm diagnosis given the asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss and absent reflexes.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation at an external institution showed normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally with a slight asymmetry in the high frequencies (left ear worse). No middle ear or reflex data were reported.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing bilaterally; PTA Right 8 dB HL, Left 11 dB HL. Slight asymmetry at 4000 and 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 10 dB HL bilaterally; WRS 100% at 55 dB HL bilaterally.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Pre-treatment evaluation confirmed normal hearing sensitivity but revealed significant retrocochlear signs. The absence of ipsilateral acoustic reflexes in the left ear, despite normal thresholds, combined with persistent high-frequency asymmetry, strongly supported the MRI-confirmed diagnosis of vestibular schwannoma.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing maintained; PTA Right 8 dB HL, Left 9 dB HL. Asymmetry at 8000 Hz (20 dB).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT Right 6 dB HL, Left 10 dB HL; WRS 100% at 50 dB HL bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Right ipsilateral reflexes present/normal; Left ipsilateral reflexes absent at maximum levels (>100-105 dB HL).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Slight decrease in hearing sensitivity with more obvious asymmetry; PTA Right 6 dB HL, Left 23 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: WRS Right 100% at 50 dB HL, Left slightly decreased to 88% at 60 dB HL.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Stable asymmetry; PTA Right 6 dB HL, Left 20 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: WRS Right 100% at 40 dB HL, Left 92% at 65 dB HL.

proposed_items: Stereotactic radiation (CyberKnife) to prevent further tumor growth
Monitoring of hearing and tumor status via serial audiometry and MRI
counseling_actions: Discuss the correlation between absent reflexes/asymmetry and the retrocochlear pathology
Counsel on treatment options: observation vs. radiation vs. surgery
Explain potential outcomes of radiation, including possible changes in hearing or vestibular function
Advise on the need for long-term monitoring

red_flags_present: Absent acoustic reflexes with normal hearing sensitivity

escalation.rationale_short: Tumor growth observed on MRI necessitates intervention (stereotactic radiation).

follow_up_plan.objective: Comprehensive audiological examination to monitor hearing status post-radiation.

expected_outcome: Patient maintained completely serviceable bilateral hearing and required no amplification devices.
